Hey there, fellow programmers! Are you ready to embark on a new coding journey? If you’re tired of the same old programming languages and want to try something fun and exciting, join me as I explore the fascinating world of Zig. ğŸš€
What is Zig, you ask? ğŸ¤” Zig is a modern, general-purpose programming language that’s designed for robustness, optimal performance, and simplicity. It’s built to tackle common programming pain points, like memory safety and resource management, with a fresh and user-friendly approach.
Why should I care about Zig? ğŸ§ Great question! Here are some reasons to give Zig a shot:
Safety first: Zig aims to minimize bugs and undefined behavior by offering a strong type system and compile-time checks. Efficient and fast: Zig is designed with performance in mind, providing you with the tools to write lean and fast code. No more C woes: Zig is an excellent alternative for systems programming, offering better safety guarantees and simpler syntax than C. Cross-compilation magic: With Zig, cross-compiling your code for different platforms is a breeze. Friendly and growing community: Zig boasts a warm and welcoming community that’s eager to help newcomers and contribute to the language’s growth. Getting started with Zig ğŸš€ To begin your Zig adventure, follow these simple steps:
Installation: Head over to the official Zig website to download the Zig compiler for your operating system. âš ï¸ Take heed, dear reader! This blog has been crafted using Zig version 0.10.1. Please be aware that the examples provided herein might not function as expected if you’re employing a different version of Zig.
$ zig version Output
0.10.1 Editor setup: Choose your favorite code editor and set it up for Zig development. Visual Studio Code, Vim, and Emacs all have Zig support. Hello, Zig!: Start by writing a classic “Hello, World!” program. Open your editor, create a new file called hello.zig, and type the following code: const std = @import("std"); pub fn main() void { std.debug.print("Hello, World!\n", .{}); } Compilation: Open your terminal, navigate to the folder containing hello.zig, and run the following command to compile your program: zig build-exe hello.zig Execution: Run your freshly compiled hello executable and watch the magic unfold: ./hello You should see “Hello, World!” printed on your screen. Congrats! You’ve just taken your first step into the fantastic world of Zig. ğŸ‰
What’s next? ğŸŒŸ Now that you’ve had a taste of Zig, I bet you’re itching to learn more! Here are some resources to help you dive deeper into this amazing language:
Zig Documentation: The official language reference is a treasure trove of information. Zig Community: Explore open-source Zig projects to see how others are using the language. Stay tuned for more fun and friendly blog posts about Zig. Happy Zig-zagging, everyone! ğŸˆğŸ‰

Hey there, Zig enthusiasts! ğŸ‘‹ In our previous posts, we’ve covered various aspects of the Zig programming language. But before we can dive into more advanced topics, let’s make sure everyone has Zig up and running on their systems. In this post, we’ll guide you through installing Zig on Linux, Windows, and macOS. Let’s get started! ğŸš€
âš ï¸ Take heed, dear reader! This blog has been crafted using Zig version 0.10.1. Please be aware that the examples provided herein might not function as expected if you’re employing a different version of Zig.
$ zig version Output
0.10.1 Installing Zig on Linux ğŸ§ For Linux users, you can install Zig using the pre-built packages, or you can build it from source.
Pre-built packages: Download the appropriate package for your Linux distribution from the official Zig downloads page. Extract the archive and add the zig binary to your PATH.
Building from source: If you prefer to build Zig from source, follow these steps:
Install the required dependencies: build-essential, cmake, and git. Clone the Zig repository: git clone https://github.com/ziglang/zig.git Change to the cloned directory: cd zig Create a build directory: mkdir build && cd build Run CMake to configure the build: cmake .. Build Zig: make Add the zig binary to your PATH. Installing Zig on Windows ğŸ’» For Windows users, you can install Zig using the pre-built packages or the package manager Scoop.
Pre-built packages: Download the appropriate package for your system from the official Zig downloads page. Extract the archive and add the zig binary to your PATH.
Scoop: If you have Scoop installed, you can install Zig by running: scoop install zig
Installing Zig on macOS ğŸ For macOS users, you can install Zig using the pre-built packages, Homebrew, or MacPorts.
Pre-built packages: Download the appropriate package for your system from the official Zig downloads page. Extract the archive and add the zig binary to your PATH.
Homebrew: If you have Homebrew installed, you can install Zig by running: brew install zig
MacPorts: If you have MacPorts installed, you can install Zig by running: sudo port install zig
That’s it! You should now have Zig installed on your Linux, Windows, or macOS system. ğŸ‰
What’s next? ğŸŒŸ With Zig installed, you’re ready to explore more advanced topics and unleash the full power of this exciting language! Stay tuned for more blog posts on advanced Zig topics, like error handling, concurrency, and interfacing with C libraries. As always, let’s keep exploring the world of Zig together! ğŸš€
Happy coding, and see you in the next post! ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’»ğŸŒ

Greetings, Zig enthusiasts! ğŸ‘‹ In our previous posts, we’ve explored various aspects of the Zig programming language. Now, it’s time to set up a comfortable development environment to enhance your Zig coding experience. In this post, we’ll guide you through configuring Visual Studio Code (VS Code) for Zig development, including code editing, running, and debugging. Let’s dive in! ğŸš€
âš ï¸ Take heed, dear reader! This blog has been crafted using Zig version 0.10.1. Please be aware that the examples provided herein might not function as expected if you’re employing a different version of Zig.
$ zig version Output
0.10.1 Setting up Visual Studio Code for Zig Development ğŸ› ï¸ To set up VS Code for Zig development, follow these steps:
Install Visual Studio Code: If you haven’t already, download and install Visual Studio Code for your platform (Linux, Windows, or macOS).
Install the Zig extension: Launch VS Code Quick Open (Ctrl+P), paste the following command, and press enter.
ext install ziglang.vscode-zig Configure settings: To configure the Zig extension settings, open the Settings editor by clicking on the gear icon in the lower left corner of the window and selecting “Settings.” Search for “Zig” in the search bar, and update the settings as needed. For example, you might want to set the path to your Zig compiler if it’s not in the default location. Now you’re all set for Zig development in VS Code! ğŸ‰
Running and Debugging Zig Code in VS Code ğŸƒâ€â™€ï¸ğŸ’» To run and debug Zig code in VS Code, follow these steps:
Create a new Zig file: Open VS Code, and create a new file with the .zig extension, such as main.zig.
Write some Zig code: Write a simple Zig program in your new file, such as a “Hello, World!” program:
const std = @import("std"); pub fn main() !void { std.debug.print("Hello, {s}!\n", .{"World"}); } Configure tasks.json: To run your Zig code, you need to create a tasks.json file in the .vscode folder of your workspace. Add the following configuration to the file: { "version": "2.0.0", "tasks": [ { "label": "zig build", "type": "shell", "command": "zig build-exe main.zig", "group": "build" }, { "label": "zig run", "type": "shell", "command": "main", "dependsOn": "zig build", "group": "test", "presentation": { "reveal": "always" } } ] } Run your Zig code press Ctrl+Shift+B (or Cmd+Shift+B on macOS) to run the “zig build” task, which compiles your Zig code. Then, press Ctrl+Shift+P (or Cmd+Shift+P on macOS), search for “Run Task,” and select “zig run” to execute your compiled Zig code. Output:
* Executing task: zig build-exe <...>/main.zig * Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it. Debugging: To debug your Zig code, you first need to install the “Native Debug” extension by WebFreak y CodeLLDB by Vadim Chugunov Press ctrl-p (cmd+p on OS X) and run
ext install webfreak.debug and
ext install vadimcn.vscode-lldb Once installed, create a launch.json file in the .vscode folder of your workspace with the following configuration:
{ "version": "0.2.0", "configurations": [ { "name": "Debug Zig", "type": "lldb", "request": "launch", "program": "main", "args": [], "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}", "preLaunchTask": "zig build" } ] } Debug your Zig code: Set breakpoints in your Zig code by clicking in the left margin next to the line numbers. Press F5 to start debugging. The debugger will pause at your breakpoints, allowing you to inspect variables, step through your code, and use other debugging features. That’s it! You’ve now set up Visual Studio Code for Zig development, including running and debugging your code. ğŸ‰
What’s next? ğŸŒŸ With your shiny new Zig development environment, you’re ready to explore more advanced Zig topics and build amazing projects! Stay tuned for more blog posts on advanced Zig concepts, like error handling, concurrency, and interfacing with C libraries. As always, let’s keep exploring the world of Zig together! ğŸš€
Happy coding, and see you in the next post! ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’»ğŸ¨
